[[Air Force Cross (United Kingdom)|Air Force Cross]] |laterwork= }} [[Air Vice Marshal (Australia)|Air Vice Marshal]] '''William Lloyd (Bill) Hely''', [[Order of the Bath|CB]], [[Order of the British Empire|CBE]], [[Air Force Cross (United Kingdom)|AFC]] (24 August 1909 – 20 May 1970) was a senior commander in the [[Royal Australian Air Force]] (RAAF). He graduated from the [[Royal Military College, Duntroon]], in 1930 before transferring to the RAAF as a cadet pilot. Hely came to public attention in 1936–37, first when he crashed on a survey flight in the Northern Territory, and later when he undertook two successful missions to locate missing aircraft in the same vicinity. His rescue efforts earned him the [[Air Force Cross (United Kingdom)|Air Force Cross]]. After occupying staff positions during the early years of [[Military history of Australia during World War II|World War II]], Hely was appointed Officer Commanding [[No. 72 Wing RAAF|No. 72 Wing]] in [[Netherlands New Guinea|Dutch New Guinea]] in May 1944. Later that year he formed [[No. 84 Wing RAAF|No. 84 (Army Cooperation) Wing]], commanding it during the [[Bougainville Campaign]] until the end of the Pacific War. Hely spent the immediate post-war period on the staff of RAAF Headquarters, [[Melbourne]]. From 1951 to 1953 he served as [[Air Officer Commanding]] (AOC) [[Western Area Command (RAAF)|Western Area Command]] in [[Perth]], after which he was appointed a [[Commander of the Order of the British Empire]]. He was [[Deputy Chief of Air Force (Australia)|Deputy Chief of the Air Staff]] from 1953 to 1956, AOC [[Air Force Training Group RAAF|Training Command]] from 1956 to 1957, and Head of the Australian Joint Services Staff in Washington, D.C. from 1957 to 1960. He then served as Air Member for Personnel (AMP) for six years, his tenure coinciding with a significant increase in manpower to meet commitments in South East Asia and the demands of a major re-equipment program. Having been promoted acting [[air vice marshal]] in 1953 ([[Military rank#Types of rank|substantive]] in 1956), he was appointed a [[Companion of the Order of the Bath]] in 1964 for his service as AMP. He retired from the Air Force in 1966 and made his home in [[Canberra]], where he died in 1970 at the age of sixty. ==Early career== [[File:RAAFDuntroonCadets1930.jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.2|Pilot Officer Hely (seated, left) with fellow ex-students of the Royal Military College, Duntroon, who transferred to the RAAF in December 1930, including Bill Garing (standing, left), Douglas Candy (standing, centre) and Alister Murdoch (standing, right)|alt=Portrait of eleven men in military uniforms with peaked caps, seven standing and four seated]] The third child of Prosper Frederick Hely, a storekeeper, and his wife Alice (née Lloyd), William Lloyd (Bill) Hely was born on 24 August 1909 at [[Wellington, New South Wales|Wellington]], New South Wales. He was educated to [[Intermediate Certificate (Australia)|Intermediate Certificate]] level at [[Mudgee]], [[Wollongong]] and [[Rozelle, New South Wales|Rozelle]] Public Schools, and at [[Fort Street High School]], Petersham.{{cite web|last=Eaton|first=Brian|url=http://adb.anu.edu.au/biography/hely-william-lloyd-bill-10480/text18591|title=Hely, William Lloyd (Bill) (1909–1970)|work= [[Australian Dictionary of Biography]]|accessdate= 28 May 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/Contents/About-APDC/About-APDC/Office-of-Air-Force-History/Air-Marshals-of-the-RAAF/135/Air-Vice-Marshals-A-K.aspx |title=Air Vice-Marshals (A–K) |work=Air Marshals of the RAAF|publisher=Air Power Development Centre|accessdate=28 May 2013}} Leaving school in 1926, he worked as a [[clerk]] and studied accountancy in his spare time. On 16 February 1927, Hely entered the [[Royal Military College, Duntroon]], as one of four cadets sponsored that year by the [[Royal Australian Air Force]] (RAAF), which did not yet have its own officer training college.Coulthard-Clark, ''The Third Brother'', pp. 193, 196–197 He graduated as a [[lieutenant]] on 9 December 1930, and the following day enlisted in the RAAF.Frost, ''RAAF College & Academy'', xv{{cite web|url=http://www.ww2roll.gov.au/Veteran.aspx?ServiceId=R&VeteranId=1205191|title=Hely, William Lloyd|work= World War 2 Nominal Roll|accessdate=28 May 2013}} As well as the four graduates the Air Force had enrolled in 1927, budgetary constraints imposed during the [[Great Depression]] necessitated the transfer from Duntroon to Point Cook of eight other RAAF-sponsored cadets midway through their four-year course, including [[Alister Murdoch]], [[Bill Garing]] and [[Douglas Candy]]. Initially ranked [[pilot officer]], Hely commenced his flying training course at [[RAAF Williams#RAAF William Point Cook Base|RAAF Point Cook]], Victoria, on 15 January 1931, graduating on 10 December.Coulthard-Clark, ''The Third Brother'', p. 198 His early postings as a pilot in 1932 and 1933 were to [[RAAF Base Richmond|RAAF Station Richmond]], New South Wales, and [[RAAF Williams#RAAF William Laverton Base|RAAF Station Laverton]], Victoria. Qualifying in aerial photography, he served at Point Cook from 1933 to 1936. He was then transferred to [[No. 3 Squadron RAAF|No. 3 Squadron]] at Richmond, receiving promotion to [[flight lieutenant]].{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article11028061 |title=Three men missing in aeroplane |newspaper=[[The Argus (Australia)|The Argus]] |location=Melbourne |date=16 April 1936 |accessdate=28 May 2013 |page=11 |publisher=[[National Library of Australia]]}} [[File:Crashed Dragon Rapide 1936 (AWM P02307.034).jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.2|Dragon Rapide piloted by Flight Lieutenant Hely that crash landed in the Northern Territory, 1936|alt=Monoplane lying in pieces in scrub]] In April 1936, Hely took command of No. 3 Squadron's North Australia Survey Flight, one of two such [[Flight (military unit)|flights]] formed by the Air Force that month to carry out photographic surveys. Flying a twin-engined [[de Havilland Dragon Rapide]] (serial number A3-2), Hely departed Richmond on 11 April for [[Port Hedland, Western Australia|Port Hedland]], which was to be the flight's base for its initial survey work in Western Australia. Over the Northern Territory, between [[Newcastle Waters, Northern Territory|Newcastle Waters]] and [[Kalkarindji, Northern Territory|Wave Hill]], he became lost, ran out of fuel, and had to crash land. He and his crew of two were found by RAAF search aircraft ten days later, on 22 April.Coulthard-Clark, ''The Third Brother'', pp. 431–432 [[The Argus (Australia)|''The Argus'']] had reported that "grave fears" were held for their safety, but they were largely uninjured, Hely having suffered cuts and abrasions to his head and leg.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article17328716 |title=Flight-Lieut. Hely's graphic account|newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |location=Sydney |date=25 April 1936 |accessdate=28 May 2013 |page=15 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} The aircraft was badly damaged and had to be transported back to Richmond in pieces. In February 1937, Hely took part in the search for a missing [[Stinson Model A|Stinson]] airliner that was eventually found in the [[McPherson Range]], Queensland, five of its seven passengers and crew dead.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article36891598 |title=25 Planes seek in vain for missing Stinson|newspaper=[[The Courier-Mail]] |location=Brisbane |date=22 February 1937 |accessdate=28 May 2013 |page=13 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article87583451 |title=Missing airliner found |newspaper=[[Kalgoorlie Miner]] |location=Kalgoorlie, Western Australia|date=1 March 1937 |accessdate=28 May 2013 |page=4 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} For its 1937 aerial survey program, the RAAF formed the Communications and Survey Flight under [[No. 1 Aircraft Depot RAAF|No. 1 Aircraft Depot]]'s Recruit Training Squadron at Laverton on 3 May. The flight was divided into Western and Eastern Air Detachments, the former under Hely. Flying a [[Tugan Gannet]], Hely's first task became searching for survey director Sir Herbert Gepp, whose Rapide (A3-2, the same one Hely crash landed the previous year) had gone missing on an inspection flight in the Northern Territory between [[Tennant Creek]] and [[Tanami Desert|Tanimi]]. Hely located the downed Rapide on 23 May, guiding in a ground party that was able to clear a makeshift runway and allow Gepp and his team to take off and resume their journey.Coulthard-Clark, ''The Third Brother'', pp. 433–435 On 25 September, Hely was again diverted from survey work to search for a lost plane, this time the [[de Havilland DH.60 Moth|de Havilland Gipsy Moth]] of [[Royal Flying Doctor Service of Australia|flying doctor]] [[Clyde Fenton]], who had gone missing north-east of Newcastle Waters. Hely, once more piloting Rapide A3-2, found the Moth three days later and landed to rescue the lost doctor. Fenton was subsequently quoted as saying "I have only the highest praise for the efficient manner in which Hely conducted a difficult search and the skilful way in which he located me and picked me up".Coulthard-Clark, ''The Third Brother'', pp. 436–437 The rescue efforts made Hely one of the RAAF's best-known public figures.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article2445621 |title=Plane Crash |newspaper=[[The Canberra Times]] |location=Canberra|date=22 November 1937 |accessdate=28 May 2013 |page=2 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} Completing his posting to the survey flight, he served as [[adjutant]] at Laverton in 1938. He was awarded the [[Air Force Cross (United Kingdom)|Air Force Cross]] on 9 June for "zeal and initiative in searching for Sir Herbert Gepp's party and later for Dr. Fenton when lost in Central Australia".{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article95949100 |title=Seven knighthoods in eastern states |newspaper=The Recorder |location=Port Pirie, South Australia |date=9 June 1938 |accessdate=28 May 2013 |page=1 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}{{LondonGazette|issue= 34518|supp=yes|startpage=3709|date=9 June 1938|accessdate=on 28 May 2013}} On 29 November 1938, he married secretary Jean McDonald at St Aidan's Anglican Church in [[Launceston, Tasmania|Launceston]], Tasmania; the couple would have two daughters. Hely spent the following year in Britain, attending the [[Royal Air Force Staff College, Andover]], and was promoted to [[squadron leader]] in September. ==World War II== [[File:OG2268JonesHely1945.jpg|thumb|right|Group Captain Hely (left) as Officer Commanding No. 84 Wing, with the [[Chief of Air Force (Australia)|Chief of the Air Staff]], Air Vice-Marshal [[George Jones (RAAF officer)|George Jones]], on Bougainville, in February 1945|alt=Two men in light-coloured military uniforms sitting in a jeep]] At the outbreak of World War II, Hely was attached to the operations room at [[RAF Coastal Command]]. On his return to Australia in January 1940, he was appointed Staff Officer Plans at RAAF Headquarters, [[Melbourne]]. In October, he joined the [[Deputy Chief of Air Force (Australia)|Deputy Chief of the Air Staff]], Air Vice Marshal [[William Bostock|Bill Bostock]], as a delegate to a defence conference in Singapore. The Australian contingent found the local forces ill-prepared for an attack by the Japanese and recommended significant increases in air capability, both in Australia and the Pacific Islands, to meet the threat.Gillison, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/26/chapters/07.pdf ''Royal Australian Air Force'', pp. 143–144] Hely was promoted to temporary [[Wing commander (rank)|wing commander]] the following January, and was the ranking Air Force delegate at a series of staff talks in [[Jakarta|Batavia]] and Singapore regarding the defence of the [[Dutch East Indies]].{{cite web|url=http://www.awm.gov.au/journal/j29/herman.asp|last=Bussemaker|first=Herman|title=Australian-Dutch defence cooperation, 1940–1941|work=Journal of the Australian War Memorial, Issue 29|date=November 1996|accessdate=2 June 2013}} He became Director of Operations at RAAF Headquarters in August. His promotion to acting [[group captain]] was announced on 17 February 1942.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article91516776 |title=Airman promoted |newspaper=[[The Examiner (Tasmania)|The Examiner]] |location=Launceston, Tasmania |date=17 February 1942 |accessdate=28 May 2013 |page=4 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} Two days later, the [[Bombing of Darwin|Japanese bombed]] [[Darwin, Northern Territory|Darwin]], Northern Territory; Hely circulated a memo early the next month to all commands on the lessons learnt from the raid.Helson, ''The Forgotten Air Force'', pp. 70–71, 80–81 He was posted to Darwin in May to join [[North-Western Area Command (RAAF)|North-Western Area]] headquarters as senior air staff officer, and was granted the temporary rank of group captain in January 1943.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article11340372 |title=Many RAAF officers promoted |newspaper=The Argus |location=Melbourne |date=29 January 1943 |accessdate=28 May 2013 |page=3 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} Hely returned to RAAF Headquarters in March to become Director of Air Staff Plans. In May 1944, Hely assumed command of [[No. 72 Wing RAAF|No. 72 Wing]] at [[Merauke]], Dutch New Guinea, succeeding Group Captain [[Allan Walters]].{{cite web|last=Funnell|first=Ray|authorlink=Ray Funnell|url=http://adb.anu.edu.au/biography/walters-allan-leslie-11954/text21425|title=Walters, Allan Leslie (1905–1968)|work= Australian Dictionary of Biography|accessdate= 28 May 2013}} Comprising fighter and dive-bomber squadrons, the wing had been established to undertake air defence and patrol tasks in and around [[Western New Guinea campaign|western New Guinea]].Odgers, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/27/chapters/07.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', pp. 114–116] Hely departed Merauke in September 1944 to establish an army cooperation formation, [[No. 84 Wing RAAF|No. 84 Wing]], in [[Cairns]], Queensland. It was one of two such wings formed by the RAAF in the [[South West Pacific Theatre of World War II|South West Pacific Theatre]] late in World War II.Odgers, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/27/chapters/19.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', pp. 318–327]Odgers, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/27/chapters/26.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', p. 440] They were, as described by the [[Australia in the War of 1939–1945|official history of the RAAF in the Pacific]], "essentially non-offensive in character", responsible for reconnaissance, artillery spotting, supply drops to ground forces, spraying [[DDT]] to combat [[malaria]], and guiding [[Close air support|close support]] aircraft to their objectives. The wing could also carry out its own strikes on "[[Target of opportunity|targets of opportunity]]".Odgers, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/27/chapters/18.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', p. 317] No. 84 Wing comprised [[No. 5 Squadron RAAF|No. 5 (Tactical Reconnaissance) Squadron]], [[No. 17 Air Observation Post Flight RAAF|No. 17 Air Observation Post Flight]], No. 10 Communication Unit (subsequently renamed [[No. 10 Local Air Supply Unit RAAF|No. 10 Local Air Supply Unit]]), and No. 39 Operational Base Unit. It deployed to [[Torokina]] in October to support Australian troops during the [[Bougainville Campaign]]. No. 5 Squadron, equipped with [[CAC Boomerang]]s and [[CAC Wirraway|Wirraways]], was assigned to mark targets for [[Vought F4U Corsair|F4U Corsairs]] of the [[Royal New Zealand Air Force]].Parnell; Lynch, ''Australian Air Force Since 1911'', p. 97 Between December 1944 and January 1945, the wing lost one Auster, one Wirraway, and one Boomerang on operations. Despite shortages of pilots and equipment, Hely's formation was generally able to keep pace with the army's requirements. By the end of June 1945, it had flown over 4,000 [[sortie]]s. ==Post-war career== [[File:OperationHurricane.png|thumb|left|Air Commodore Hely coordinated RAAF support for the British atomic test at Montebello, Western Australia, in 1952|alt=Front page of ''The West Australian'' newspaper for 4 October 1952; the headline reads "Britain test her first atomic bomb off W.A. coast"]] Hely relinquished command of No. 84 Wing on 12 August 1945 and returned to RAAF Headquarters in October.{{cite web|author=No. 84 (Army Cooperation) Wing|title=Operations record book |url=http://recordsearch.naa.gov.au/scripts/Imagine.asp?B=1753386| page=31|accessdate=28 May 2013}} He was by this time among a coterie of officers at group captain level, including [[Valston Hancock|Val Hancock]], Alister Murdoch and Bill Garing, earmarked by the Australian Air Board for leadership roles in the post-war RAAF, which was to shrink rapidly with demobilisation.Helson, ''Ten Years at the Top'', pp. 237–238Stephens, ''Going Solo'', pp. 24–27 At RAAF Headquarters, Hely was appointed Deputy Director of Operations, in which capacity he served on a committee to investigate proposals for an officer training college, later established as [[RAAF College]], Point Cook. Along with Hely, all officers associated with the proposal's examination were former Duntroon students, including the Deputy Chief of the Air Staff, Air Commodore [[Frank Bladin]], the Director of Postings, Group Captain Murdoch, and the Director of Training, Group Captain Paddy Heffernan. Another Duntroon graduate, Air Commodore Hancock, became the college's first commandant.Frost, ''RAAF College & Academy'', pp. 1–2, 9 Hely was appointed Director of Organisation and Staff Duties in 1946. That November, he became Director of Postings.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article22381408 |title=Appointments to high RAAF posts |newspaper=The Argus |location=Melbourne |date=9 November 1946 |accessdate=28 May 2013 |page=3 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} The following year, he took up the position of Director of Personal Services, before departing for Britain in December 1948 to study at the [[Royal College of Defence Studies|Imperial Defence College, London]]. Returning to Melbourne, Hely served as deputy to the Air Member for Personnel from January 1950. He became an [[aide-de-camp]] to [[George VI|King George VI]] in June 1951.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article18226655 |title=Australians as aides to the King |newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald |location=Sydney |date=8 June 1951 |accessdate=28 May 2013 |page=4 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} In September, he was appointed [[Officer Commanding]] [[Western Area Command (RAAF)|Western Area]], [[Perth]], taking up his new post in mid-October.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article48989237 |title=New officer appointed to lead RAAF in WA |newspaper=[[The West Australian]] |location=Perth|date=8 September 1951 |accessdate=28 May 2013 |page=2 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article48991572 |title=New air chief on citizen training |newspaper=The West Australian |location=Perth |date=24 September 1951 |accessdate=28 May 2013 |page=2 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} He was promoted to acting [[air commodore]] in July 1952, becoming [[Air Officer Commanding]] (AOC) Western Area.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article49039589 |title=Promotion in RAAF |newspaper=The West Australian |location=Perth |date=2 July 1952 |accessdate=28 May 2013 |page=7 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} His rank was made permanent in September, and the same month he was appointed aide-de-camp to [[Elizabeth II|Queen Elizabeth II]].{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article49050990 |title=Six RAAF officers promoted|newspaper=The West Australian |location=Perth |date=5 September 1952 |accessdate=28 May 2013 |page=4 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article18281320 |title=Aides-de-camp to the Queen |newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald |location=Sydney|date=12 September 1952 |accessdate=28 May 2013 |page=5 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} Among Hely's duties as AOC Western Area was coordinating air support for the [[Operation Hurricane|British atomic test]] on [[Montebello Islands|Montebello]] in October 1952, including supply and observation flights by [[Douglas C-47 Skytrain|Dakotas]] of [[No. 86 Wing RAAF|No. 86 (Transport) Wing]].{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article65504778 |title=Atomic Weapon Tested |newspaper=[[Benalla Ensign]] |location=Victoria |date=27 November 1952 |accessdate=2 April 2013 |page=11 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} He was appointed a [[Commander of the Order of the British Empire]] (CBE) in the [[Coronation of Queen Elizabeth II|Queen's Coronation Honours]] promulgated on 1 June 1953, for his war service and his work during the Montebello test.{{LondonGazette|issue= 39865|supp=yes|startpage=2998|date=1 June 1953|accessdate=on 28 May 2013}}{{cite magazine|magazine=RAAF News, Vol. 8, No. 8|title=RAAF Air Board member retires |date= September 1966|page=3}} In August, he was named Deputy Chief of the Air Staff (DCAS), with the acting rank of [[air vice marshal]], effective from October; he replaced Air Vice Marshal Hancock.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article49228613 |title=Hely will be Deputy Chief of Air Staff |newspaper=The West Australian |location=Perth |date=25 August 1953 |accessdate=28 May 2013 |page=3 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} Between October 1953 and February 1954, the RAAF underwent major organisational change, as it transitioned from a geographically based command-and-control system to one based on function, resulting in the establishment of [[RAAF Air Command|Home]] (operational), [[Air Force Training Group RAAF|Training]], and Maintenance Commands. At the same time, RAAF Headquarters in Melbourne was absorbed by the [[Department of Air (Australia)|Department of Air]] in Canberra.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', pp. 74–77 Hely was acting Air Member for Personnel from 3 January to 7 March 1955, between the terms of Air Vice Marshals Val Hancock and [[Frederick Scherger|Fred Scherger]].Stephens, ''Going Solo'', pp. 499–500 On 24 January 1956, he became AOC Training Command, taking over from Air Vice Marshal Murdoch.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article72532168 |title=RAAF's new training chief |newspaper=The Argus |location=Melbourne|date=25 January 1956 |accessdate=28 May 2013 |page=8 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} He was succeeded as DCAS by Air Vice Marshal Douglas Candy.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71795620 |title=New deputy air chief |newspaper=The Argus |location=Melbourne |date=4 April 1956 |accessdate=10 March 2014 |page=3 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} Hely's rank of air vice marshal became [[Military rank#Types of rank|substantive]] on 5 September. In January 1957, Point Cook retired its last [[de Havilland Tiger Moth]] trainers, signalling the end of the biplane era in the RAAF.{{cite web|url=http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/HistoryRecord/HistoryRecordDetail.aspx?rid=171|title=Goodbye to the Tiger Moth|publisher=Air Power Development Centre|date=9 January 1957|accessdate=28 May 2013}} That May, Hely was seconded to the [[Department of Defence (Australia)|Department of Defence]] and posted to Washington, D.C., to head up the Australian Joint Services Staff. He was succeeded as AOC Training Command by Air Vice Marshal [[Ian Dougald McLachlan|Ian McLachlan]].{{cite web|url=http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/Contents/About-APDC/About-APDC/Office-of-Air-Force-History/Air-Marshals-of-the-RAAF/137/Air-Vice-Marshals-L-Z.aspx |title=Air Vice-Marshals (L–Z) |work=Air Marshals of the RAAF|publisher=Air Power Development Centre|accessdate=28 May 2013}} [[File:AVMBillHely.jpg|thumb|Air Vice Marshal Hely as Air Member for Personnel|alt=Head-and-shoulders portrait of man in dark uniform with peaked cap and pilot's wings on left-breast pocket]] Hely became Air Member for Personnel (AMP) on 28 March 1960, taking over from the acting AMP, Air Commodore [[Frank Headlam]]. Responsible for the Personnel Branch of the RAAF, the position of AMP occupied a seat on the Air Board, the service's controlling body that comprised its senior officers and was chaired by the [[Chief of Air Force (Australia)|Chief of the Air Staff]] (CAS).Stephens, ''Going Solo'', pp. 88–89Stephens, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', p. 52 The Air Force expanded greatly during Hely's term as AMP, owing to Australia's increasing commitment to the security of South East Asia, and the most significant rearmament program the RAAF had undertaken outside of World War II. Its permanent establishment increased from a steady 15,000 or so in the 1950s to over 18,000 by 1966.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', p. 501 Hely himself initiated a scheme to attract staff from the [[Royal Air Force]], which was suffering cutbacks, by opening a recruitment office in London and taking advantage of the Australian government's [[Ten Pound Poms|assisted passage scheme]] to import trained personnel and their families. He was appointed a [[Companion of the Order of the Bath]] (CB) in the 1964 [[New Year Honours]] for his "tactful and careful handling of personnel matters", and for having "done much to improve the manning level of the Air Force".{{LondonGazette|issue=43201|supp=yes|startpage=35|date=1 January 1964|accessdate=on 28 May 2013}}{{cite magazine|magazine=RAAF News, Vol. 6, No. 1|title=Nineteen in honours list|date= January–February 1964|page=7}} As AMP, Hely put forward proposals to increase the number of [[diploma]]-qualified engineering and equipment officers in the Air Force.Coulthard-Clark, ''From the Ground Up'', pp. 109–113 He was also closely involved in deliberations concerning the balance of academic and military studies at the RAAF Academy (previously RAAF College), the outcome of which is considered to have left the course biased towards pure science, rather than its applications to air power.Frost, ''RAAF College & Academy'', pp. 49–52Stephens, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', pp. 188–189 ==Retirement== Hely retired on 24 August 1966, after almost forty years in the military.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article107888831 |title=Senior RAAF officer retires |newspaper=The Canberra Times |location=Canberra |date=25 August 1966 |accessdate=28 May 2013 |page=24 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} He was succeeded the following day as AMP by Air Vice Marshal Candy. In retirement, Hely was active in the Canberra branch of the Air Force Association. He died of cancer in Canberra on 20 May 1970. Survived by his wife and children, he was accorded an Air Force funeral at [[St John the Baptist Church, Reid|St John the Baptist Church]] and cremated at Norwood Park Crematorium, [[Gungahlin]].{{cite magazine|magazine=RAAF News, Vol. 12, No. 6|title=Tributes to AVM Hely|date= July 1970|page=3}} The official mourning party included [[Chief of the Defence Force (Australia)|Chairman of the Chiefs of Staff Committee]] (CCOSC) General [[John Wilton (general)|Sir John Wilton]], former CCOSC Air Chief Marshal Sir Frederick Scherger, [[Department of Defence (Australia)#Diarchy|Secretary of Defence]] [[Arthur Tange|Sir Arthur Tange]], CAS Air Marshal [[Colin Hannah]], former CAS Air Marshal Sir Alister Murdoch, Vice Admiral [[Victor Smith|Sir Victor Smith]], Air Vice Marshal [[Brian Eaton]], and Group Captain [[John Lloyd Waddy|John Waddy]].
